On Sat, Apr 26, 2008 at 7:14 PM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
>  It sounds like you see the long view as a process in which we
>  gradually figure out how to make the AI more and more general.
>
>  But is that a mismatch to evolutionary computation? I feel like
>  that's more the long view of reinforcement learning (RL) than
>  neuroevolution.
>
>  In NE, our long view seems more to be about harnessing the power of
>  evolution, and evolutionary "learning" is quite different and quite a
>  bit less general than human learning.

The way I think of the distinction is between:

phylogenetic (evolutionary) learning: weights are "hard-wired" and
adjusted by evolution
ontogenetic (lifetime) learning: weights are modified by experience
during lifespan

These types of learning obviously aren't mutually exclusive. I think
in many organisms, such as insects, their behavior is predominantly a
result of phylogenetic learning. Even so, such behaviors can be
incredibly flexible and complex. But the evolution of the neocortex
was a major shift in evolution, usurping most brain functions with a
very uniform, generic computing structure, and so ontogenetic learning
outstripped phlylogenetic learning.

I think evolutionary algorithms have a place in developing hard-wired
solutions to difficult problems. There are many problems for which you
wouldn't necessarily want a generic learner, which is going to require
extensive training. I also think that evolutionary algorithms will be
useful in optimizing the parameters of a uniform, generic computing
structure, such as an artificial neocortex. Obviously, such an
approach would need to be coupled with learning algorithms, e.g.
Hebbian-like learning modulated by a reward signal (RL).

>  In RL, in contrast, the long view is almost the opposite: They want to
>  remove all constraints and still learn nevertheless.

I'm not sure what you mean by this, Ken. Could you elaborate a little?

> My aim is to design an
>  algorithm that will output a brain, not to design the brain itself.

But what kind of brain are you wanting to output?

--Derek
